Starting from his birth in Baxi, ending with his arrival in Gaochang from the West
The Dharma Master's name was Xuanzang, with the surname Chen, and was a person from Chenliu.
He was a descendant of Zhonggong, the Grand Master of Taiqiu of the Han Dynasty.
His great-grandfather Qin was the Prefect of Shangdang in the Later Wei Dynasty.

His grandfather Kang served the Qi Dynasty with his learning and was appointed as the Academician for the Palace University. He was granted the fief of Zhounan. His descendants lived there and were also people of Baxi.

His father Hui had a noble and upright character. He was well-versed in scriptures and techniques from an early age. He was eight feet tall, with beautiful eyebrows and bright eyes. He wore a long robe and a wide belt, and liked the appearance of a Confucian scholar. People of the time compared him to Guo Youdao.
By nature, he was tranquil and simple, not striving for fame and advancement. Moreover, as the governance of the Sui Dynasty was declining, he immersed himself in the ancient classics.
The prefect and the governor frequently recommended him as a filial and incorruptible official, but he declined on the grounds of illness. Those who knew him admired him.
He had four sons, and the Dharma Master was the fourth son.
From a young age, he was exceptionally intelligent and his wisdom surpassed others.

When he was eight years old, his father was sitting beside a table, orally teaching him the Great Learning. When he reached the passage about Zengzi rising from his seat, he suddenly adjusted his robe and stood up.
He was asked the reason, and he replied:
When Zengzi heard the teacher's instructions, he rose from his seat. Xuanzang now receives his father's kind teachings, how could he remain seated?
His father was very pleased and knew he would surely succeed.
He called the clan members and told them, they all congratulated him, saying:
This is the one who will bring glory to our family!
His early wisdom was like this.

From then on, he thoroughly understood the profound scriptures. He loved the ancients and esteemed the virtuous, not reading anything that was not elegant and correct, not practicing anything that was not the way of the sages and wise men;
he did not associate with young people, did not enter the bustling streets;
Although bells and drums were noisy on the main road, and various performances and singing were held in the alleys, with crowds of men and women gathering, he never went out.
Moreover, he had little knowledge of nourishing the body, keeping warm, and being pure and diligent.
His second elder brother, Chang Jie, had already left home and lived at Jingtu Temple in the Eastern Capital.
Observing that Dharma Master Fa was capable of transmitting the Dharma teachings, he took him to the Daoist temple to recite and study the scriptures.

Soon there was an edict to ordain two groups of seven monks in Luoyang. At that time, there were several hundred who excelled in practice. Dharma Master, being young, did not participate in the selection. He stood by the side of the official gate.
At that time, the commissioner, the Grand Minister of the Imperial Secretariat Zheng Shanguo, who had the discernment of a scholar, saw him and found him extraordinary. He asked:
Whose son are you?
He replied with his family name and clan.
He asked again:
Are you seeking ordination?ğŸ”½He answered:
Yes.
But because my recent practice is slight, I have not been selected.
He asked again:
What is the purpose of leaving home?
He replied:
I wish to inherit the TathÄgata's teachings from afar, and to illuminate the bequeathed Dharma nearby.
Guo deeply admired his aspiration and also valued his appearance, so he specially accepted him.
He then said to the officials:
Reciting the scriptures is easy to accomplish, but a person with such a unique appearance is hard to find.
If I ordain this child, he will surely become a great vessel for the Buddhist teachings, but I am afraid that Guo and the officials will not see him soar in the clouds and rain down sweet dew.
Moreover, his family name cannot be lost.
Judging from the present, Zheng Qing's words were not false.

After being ordained, he stayed with his elder brother. At that time, the temple had a master named Jing who lectured on the Nirvana Sutra. He held the scroll and bowed his head in reverence, and thus forgot to eat and sleep.
He also studied the Compendium of the Great Vehicle Treatise with Master Yan, and his love and admiration surpassed the previous.
After hearing it once, he retained it all, and after reading it a second time, he had no more omissions.
Everyone was amazed and had him ascend the seat to expound. His uplifting and analysis were complete, covering the essence of his teacher's teachings.
From then on, his beautiful questions and fragrant reputation spread.
At that time, he was thirteen years old.
Later, when the Sui Dynasty lost control, the world was in turmoil.
The imperial capital became a den of Jie and Zhi, and the Yellow and Luo Rivers became a lair of jackals and wolves.
The nobility was destroyed, the monastic community perished, white bones littered the roads, and the smoke of cooking ceased.
Although Wang Mang and Dong Zhuo's rebellion caused chaos, and Liu Yuan and Shi Le's rebellion brought disaster, they had never exterminated the people and devastated the country to this extent.
Although the Dharma Master was still young, his thoughts penetrated the changes and understood the situation. He said to his elder brother:
Although this is our parents' hometown, the chaos and destruction are like this. How can we stay and die here?

I have heard that the Tang Emperor has driven out the people of Jinyang and has already occupied Chang'an. The world will rely on him as if returning to our parents. I wish to go with you, elder brother.
The elder brother followed his advice and they came together in the first year of Wude.

At that time, the foundation of the country was just established, and military affairs were still in progress. The techniques of Sun and Wu were considered urgent matters. The way of Confucius and ÅšÄkyamuni had not yet been attended to. Therefore, there were no lecture halls in the capital city. The Dharma Master deeply lamented this.
Originally, Emperor Yang built four monasteries in the Eastern Capital and summoned famous monks from all over the country to reside there.
Those who were summoned were all scholars of one skill. Therefore, Dharma masters were as numerous as forests. Jing, Tuel, Ji, and Xian were considered the foremost.
In the last years, the country was in chaos, and supplies were cut off. Many traveled to Mian and Shu. The number of those who knew the Dharma was even greater there.
The Dharma Master then said to his elder brother:
This is not a matter of wasting time without the Dharma. I wish to travel to Shu to study there.
The elder brother followed his advice.
He also went with the sutra to Ziwu Valley and entered Hanzhong, where he met the two Dharma Masters Kong and Jing, both great virtuous ones of the Dharma Realm. They met with joy and tears.
He stayed for more than a month, receiving teachings from them, and then proceeded together with them to Chengdu.

The virtuous ones gathered, and a great Dharma assembly was held. He then listened to Ji and Xian's teachings on the MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha, Abhidharma, and Dharma Master Zhen's teachings on the AbhidharmakoÅ›a. He cherished every moment and diligently studied without slacking off. In two or three years, he thoroughly studied all the texts.

At that time, the world was suffering from famine and chaos, only Shu was peaceful and prosperous, so many monks from all over the country came to Shu. There were always hundreds of people under the lecture seats.

The Dharma Master's vast talent in wisdom and principle surpassed them all. Wu, Shu, Jing, Chu, none did not know or hear of him. Those who admired him from afar were like the ancients who respected Li and Guo.
The Dharma master's elder brother resided at Kong Hui Temple in Chengdu. He also had a bright and lofty demeanor, with a tall and imposing physique, resembling their father.

He enjoyed both Buddhist and non-Buddhist studies. He lectured on the Nirvana Sutra, the Compendium of the Great Vehicle, and Abhidharma, and was also proficient in the classics and histories. He was especially good at the Laozi and Zhuangzi, and was admired by the people of Shu. The Regional Inspector, Duke of Zao, held him in high esteem.
As for composing prose and poetry, speaking eloquently, being erudite and elegant, guiding ordinary people, he was not ashamed of his younger brother.

If we speak of standing out alone, unmixed with worldly dust, roaming the eight directions, exhausting the profound principles, aspiring to encompass the universe, keeping the sages and enlightened ones in mind, supporting the collapsing net, subduing the diverse customs, traveling through wind and waves without weariness, facing the myriad chariots with an unwavering resolve, this is indeed something the elder brother could not attain.
However, the two younger brothers had noble conduct and pure rules, with fragrant reputation and elegant character. Even the brothers of Mount Lu could not surpass them.

When the Dharma Master reached the age of twenty, in the fifth year of Wude, he received full ordination in Chengdu. He sat through the summer retreat and studied the Vinaya, mastering the essentials of the five categories and seven groups in one reading.
Having thoroughly studied the scriptures and treatises of the E region, he further thought of entering the capital to inquire about the special teachings.

The regulations hindered him, and he was also detained by his elder brother, unable to fulfill his intention. He then privately formed a group with merchants, sailed up the Three Gorges, and fled along the river.
Arriving at Tianhuang Temple in Jingzhou, the monks and laypeople there had long heard of him. When he arrived, they all requested him to expound the teachings.
The Dharma Master lectured on the Compendium Treatise and the Abhidharma, each for three times from summer to winter.
At that time, the King of Hanyang, with his great virtue and noble family, served as the garrison there.
Hearing that the Dharma Master had arrived, he was very delighted and personally paid his respects.
On the day of the lecture, the king led the officials and monks and laypeople who were skilled in the arts, all gathered at the glorious hall.
Thereupon, questions arose like clouds, and debates rose like peaks. The Dharma master responded and explained, and none were not exhausted in words and subdued in intent.
Among them, those who had profound understanding were overwhelmed with emotion.
The king also praised him to the utmost, and the donations were like mountains, but he did not accept a single thing.
After the lecture ended, he traveled north again to seek out the virtuous elders.
He arrived at Xiangzhou and visited Dharma Master Xiu, asking him about doubts and obstacles.
He also went to Zhaozhou, met Dharma Master Shen, and studied the Chengshi Lun.
He then entered Chang'an and stayed at Dabei Temple, where he studied the Abhidharma-koÅ›a-Å›Ästra under Dharma Master Yue.
He completely understood the meaning of all the texts after one reading, and memorized them after just a glance. Even the senior scholars and elders could not surpass him.
As for the profound and far-reaching, revealing the subtle and hidden, what others have not reached, the unique realization of the profound and mysterious, there are indeed not one or two meanings.

At that time, there were two great virtuous ones in Chang'an, Chang and Bian, who thoroughly understood the two vehicles and practiced the three learnings. They were Dharma masters in the capital, to whom the monastics and laypeople turned. Their teachings shook the state of Shenzhou, and their fame reached the other shore. The companions carrying their books followed them like clouds. Although they comprehensively included various sÅ«tras, they specialized in lecturing on the MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha-Å›Ästra.

Since the Dharma Master had already made contributions in Wu and Shu, after arriving in Chang'an, he further followed and inquired. However, as for the profound meanings, he also completely grasped them all.
The two virtuous ones deeply admired him and said to the Dharma Master:
You can be called the thousand-li horse of the ÅšÄkya gate. The rekindling of the sun of wisdom will be in your person. We regret that we are old and decrepit and may not see it.
From then on, the students changed their views, and his praise filled the capital city.

After the Dharma Master had visited all the masters and thoroughly studied their teachings, he examined their principles in detail. Each had their own doctrinal basis, but when tested against the scriptures, there were also hidden and manifest differences, and he did not know which to follow. He then vowed to travel to the West to ask about his doubts, and to obtain the Seventeen Grounds Treatise to resolve the various doubts, which is the present Yoga Stage Treatise.
He also said:

In the past, Faxian and Zhizhan were also outstanding figures of their time. They were all able to seek the Dharma and guide the masses. How could it be that their lofty traces cannot be followed and their pure wind cannot continue after them?
A great man must continue it.
Thus, he formed a group and submitted a memorial.
But it was rejected.
All the others withdrew, only the Dharma Master did not yield.

Since he was about to travel alone, and heard that the western route was difficult and dangerous, he tested his mind himself, using the various sufferings of the human world to subdue himself, to see if he could endure without retreating.
Only then did he enter the stupa, requesting to express his intention, hoping that the myriad sages would secretly assist him, enabling him to travel back and forth without obstruction.
At the time of the Dharma Master's birth, his mother dreamed that the Dharma Master put on white clothes and went west.
The mother said:
You are my son, where do you want to go now?
He replied:
I am going to seek the Dharma.
This was a prior sign of his travels.
In the third year of the Zhenguan era, in the eighth month of autumn, he was about to set out on his journey and again sought auspicious omens.
He then dreamed at night of the great ocean with Mount Sumeru, composed of the four treasures, extremely magnificent.
He intended to climb the mountain, but the vast waves were surging, and there were no boats or rafts, but he was not afraid. He then made up his mind to enter.
Suddenly he saw a stone lotus flower emerging from the waves, appearing under his feet, but disappearing as soon as he looked at it.
In an instant, he reached the foot of the mountain, which was also steep and impassable.
He tried jumping, and his body rose up by itself, with a gust of wind coming and supporting him as he ascended.
When he reached the peak, he looked in the four directions, and there was no obstruction whatsoever. He was delighted and awakened, and then proceeded on his way.
At that time, he was twenty-six years old.

At that time, there was a monk named Xiaoda from Qinzhou who was studying the Nirvana Sutra in the capital. When his studies were completed, he returned to his hometown and then went with him.ğŸ”½When they arrived at Qinzhou, they stayed for one night. They met a companion from Lanzhou and went with him to Lanzhou.
They stayed for one night and encountered a man from Liangzhou who was sending official horses back. They went with him to Liangzhou.

They stayed there for over a month, and the monks and laypeople requested him to expound the Nirvana Sutra, the Compendium of the Great Vehicle, and the Prajnaparamita Sutra. The Dharma Master expounded them all.
Liangzhou was the capital of Hexi, bordering the Western Barbarians and the countries to the right of the Pamirs. Merchants came and went without cease.

On the day of the lecture, there were many such people who offered precious treasures, bowed their heads in praise, and returned to praise the Dharma master's virtues to their rulers, saying that he wanted to come to the west to seek the Dharma in the Brahmanic countries. For this reason, all the cities in the Western Regions were filled with joy in advance and prepared to welcome him.

On the day of the assembly's dispersal, the precious offerings were abundant, with countless gold, silver, and horses. The Dharma master accepted half of them to light lamps, and the rest were offered to various temples.
At that time, the national government was still new, and the borders were not yet far, so the common people were strictly prohibited from going out of the country.
At that time, Li Daliang was the governor of Liangzhou. Having received strict orders, he guarded the borders with particular strictness.
Someone reported to Liang, saying:
There is a monk coming from Chang'an who wants to go to the Western Regions. I don't know why.
Liang was afraid and pursued the Dharma master to ask about his reasons.
The Dharma master replied:
I want to go west to seek the Dharma.
Liang heard of this and forced him to return to the capital.

There was a Dharma Master Huiwei, the leader of Hexi, with spiritual understanding and sharp wisdom. He not only respected the Dharma Master's eloquence, but also heard of his determination to seek the Dharma, and deeply rejoiced. He secretly sent two disciples, one named Hui Lin and the other Dao Zheng, to secretly escort him westward.
From then on, he did not dare to go out in public, but hid during the day and traveled at night, and finally reached Guazhou.
At that time, the Prefect Du Guoda heard that the Dharma Master had arrived and was very happy, providing him with abundant hospitality.
The Dharma Master then inquired about the western route.
Some reported:
From here, going north for more than fifty li, there is the Hulu River, with a narrow upper part and a wide lower part, with swirling waves and rapids, too deep to cross.
Above it is the Jade Gate Pass, the road must pass through it, which is the throat of the western border.
Outside the pass, in the northwest, there are also five beacon towers, where lookouts are stationed, each separated by a hundred li, with no water or grass in between.
Beyond the five beacon towers is the Moheyan Desert, the territory of the country of Yiwu.
Hearing this, he became worried and distressed. The horse he was riding also died. Not knowing how to get out, he sat in silence for over a month.
Before he left, a report from Liangzhou arrived, saying:
There is a monk named Xuanzang who wants to enter the Western Barbarians. The prefectures and counties where he stays should strictly watch out for him and capture him.
Li Chang, an official of the prefecture who had deep faith, suspected the master and secretly showed him the report, saying:
Are you not the one mentioned here?
The master hesitated and did not reply.
Li Chang said:
You must tell the truth, master.
If it is you, I will find a way to help you.
The master then told the truth.
Li Chang, hearing this, deeply praised it as rare and said:
If you really can do this, master, I will destroy the document for you.
He then tore it up in front of the master.
He also said:
You must leave early, master.
From then on, he became even more worried and anxious.
The two young monks who accompanied him, Daozheng, went to Dunhuang first, leaving only Huilin. Knowing that he was unable to travel far, he was also sent back.
He then traded and obtained a horse, but he suffered from having no one to guide him.
In front of the Maitreya statue in the temple where he stayed, he made an appeal, wishing to find someone to guide him through the pass.
That night, a Hu monk named Dharma saw in a dream that the Dharma Master was sitting on a lotus flower heading west.
Dharma privately found it strange and came to tell him in the morning.
The Dharma Master was delighted, taking it as a sign of being able to proceed, but he told Dharma:
Dreams are false, how can they be worth mentioning?
He entered the ritual arena again to make offerings and requests.
Suddenly, a Hu man came in to make offerings to the Buddha, following the Dharma Master around two or three times.
Asking his name, he said his surname was Shi, and his personal name was Pantan.
This Hu then requested to receive the precepts, so the Dharma Master bestowed the five precepts on him.
Hu Shen was very happy and took his leave to return.
After a short while, he brought pastries and fruits to come again.
The Dharma Master saw that he was bright and strong, and his appearance was respectful, so he told him his intentions.
The Hu person agreed and said he would escort the Dharma Master past the five beacon towers.
The Dharma Master was overjoyed, so he traded more of his clothing and provisions to buy a horse and set a date with him.
The next day, as the sun was about to set, they entered the grass, and in a moment, the Hu person was followed by an old Hu man riding a skinny old red horse.
The Dharma Master's heart was not pleased, and the young Hu said:
This old man is extremely familiar with the western route. He has been to and from Yiwu more than thirty times, so I came together with him, hoping to have a discussion.
The Hu elder then said:
The western route is dangerous and evil, the Sha River is far and obstructive, with ghost-like miasmas and hot winds, few have passed through.
Even with many companions, one still often gets lost, let alone the Dharma Master alone. How can he proceed?
I hope he will consider it carefully and not lightly risk his life.
The Dharma Master replied:
I am seeking the great Dharma and heading west. If I do not reach the country of Brahmins, I will never return east.
Even if I die on the way, I will not regret it.
The Hu elder said:
If you must go, you can ride this horse of mine.
This horse has made fifteen round trips to Yiwu.
It is strong and knows the way.
Your horse is young and cannot travel far.

The Dharma Master then secretly thought, when he was about to set out from Chang'an with the intention of going west, there was a diviner named He Hongda who often made accurate predictions through reciting spells and divination.
The Dharma Master asked him to predict the outcome of his journey, and Hongda said:
You will be able to go.
It seems like you will ride an old, thin red horse with a lacquered saddle and iron in front.
Seeing that the horse the Hu person was riding was thin and red, with a lacquered saddle and iron, matching what He said, he considered it to be true and thus exchanged horses.
The old Hu man was delighted, paid respects, and took leave.
Then he packed up and set off with the young Hu man at night.
By the third watch, they reached the river and saw the jade gate from afar.
About ten li upstream from the gate, the two banks were about ten zhang wide, with pepper trees growing nearby.
The Hu man then cut wood to make a bridge, spread grass and filled sand, and drove the horse across.
After the Dharma Master crossed, he was delighted. He then unharnessed and rested, about fifty steps away from the Hu man. They each laid out their mats and slept.

After a while, the Hu man drew his sword and got up, slowly approaching the Dharma Master. Before reaching ten steps, he turned back. He did not know what it meant, suspecting the Dharma Master had a different intention.
He then got up and recited the sutra, contemplating Guanyin Bodhisattva.
When the Hu man saw this, he lay down again and fell asleep.
When it was about to dawn, the Dharma Master called him to get up to fetch water to rinse his mouth. After the meal, he was about to leave. The Hu man said:

The disciple said, The road ahead is long and dangerous, and there is no water or grass. There is only water under the five beacon towers. You must arrive at night, steal water and pass by. If you are caught at one place, you will die.
It is better to return home for safety.
The Dharma Master was firm and did not turn back. He then bowed his head and advanced, drawing his sword and stringing his bow, ordering the Dharma Master to go ahead.
The Dharma Master was unwilling to go in front. The Hu person walked a few miles by himself and stopped, saying:
I cannot go any further.
My family responsibilities are heavy, and I cannot violate the king's law.
The Dharma Master knew his intention and finally let him return.
The Hu person said:
You will definitely not reach your destination.
If you are captured, how can you lead me?
The Dharma Master replied:
Even if this body is cut into tiny particles, I will never lead you.
He made a solemn oath, and the Hu person stopped.
He was given a horse and thanked the man for his kindness.
From then on, he traveled alone through the desert, only looking at the gradually advancing piles of bones and horse dung.

After a while, there suddenly appeared hundreds of troops filling the sand and gravel, sometimes moving, sometimes stopping, all in the form of fur coats, camels, and horses, as well as banners, flags, and spears, changing appearances and shifting forms, suddenly changing a thousand times. From afar, they were extremely noticeable, but as they got closer, they became less visible.
When the Dharma Master first saw them, he thought they were bandits;
as he got closer and they disappeared, he realized they were evil ghosts.
He also heard a voice in the air saying:
Do not be afraid, do not be afraid!
Because of this, he gradually felt at ease.
After more than eighty li, he saw the first beacon fire.
Fearing that the lookout would see him, he hid in a sand ditch and only set out at night.
To the west of the beacon fire, he saw water and drank from it. After washing his hands, he wanted to take some water in his leather bag when an arrow suddenly came flying and almost hit his knee.
After a while, another arrow came, and he realized that someone had seen him. He then said loudly:
I am a monk, coming from the capital.
You should not shoot me.
He then led the horse towards the beacon fire.
The man on the beacon tower also opened the gate and came out. Seeing that it was a monk, he led him in to see the commander Wang Xiang.
Xiang ordered a fire to be lit and said:
This is not a monk from our Hexi region, but indeed seems to have come from the capital.
He asked in detail about the purpose of the journey.
The Dharma Master replied:
Commander, have you heard that the people of Liangzhou say that there is a monk named Xuanzang who wants to go to the Brahmanic countries to seek the Dharma?
He replied:
I have heard that Master Xuanzang has already returned east.
Why have you come here?
The Dharma Master showed him the treatise and letter he was carrying, as well as his name, and he then believed.
He then said:
The western road is difficult and far, and you will never reach your destination.
Now, I will not punish the teacher, but the disciple is from Dunhuang and wants to send the teacher to Dunhuang.
There is a Dharma Master Zhang Jiao there who respects the virtuous and values morality. Seeing the teacher, he will certainly be delighted. Please go to him.
The Dharma Master replied:
Zang's hometown is Luoyang. From a young age, I admired the Way.
The skilled Dharma masters in the two capitals, and the monks with a single skill in Wu and Shu, all carried their backpacks to follow me and exhausted their understanding.
In debates and discussions, I am also considered a leader of the time. How could I be inferior to the patron of Dunhuang in nurturing myself and cultivating my reputation?

However, I regret that the Buddha's teachings are incomplete in the scriptures and there are omissions in the meanings, so I do not covet life and do not fear hardships and dangers. I vow to go to the West to seek the remaining teachings.
If the patron does not encourage me but only urges me to return, how can this be considered the same in despising the dust and afflictions and jointly establishing the cause for nirvana?
If you insist on detaining me, you may punish me as you see fit, but I will never move one step east to go against my original intention.
When Xiang heard this, he felt pity and said:
I am fortunate to have met the teacher. How could I not rejoice?
The teacher is tired. Rest and sleep. I will send you off in the morning and show you the way.
He then brushed aside the mat and arranged a place for him.
At dawn, after the Dharma teacher had finished his meal, Xiang had people fill water and flour cakes and sent him off for more than ten li.
He said:

From this road, go straight to the fourth beacon tower. The people there also have a good heart and are related to your disciple. His surname is Wang and his name is Bolong. When you get there, you can say that your disciple sent you.
He wept and bowed farewell.
After leaving, he arrived at the fourth beacon tower at night, fearing that he would be detained. He wanted to silently take some water and pass by.
Before he had gone down to the water, an arrow had already arrived. He reported as before and hurried towards it. They also came down.
Entering the beacon tower, the beacon tower official asked each other, answering:
I want to go to India, passing through here, the first beacon tower Wang Xiang, the general of the guard, therefore sent me to visit.
Hearing this, they were delighted and kept him overnight, giving him a large leather bag, horse, and barley to send him off.
They said:
The teacher does not need to go to the fifth beacon tower.
The people there are rude and abrupt, fearing they will have other plans.
You can leave here for about a hundred miles, there is a wild horse spring, get more water.
From here on, it is the Moheyan Desert, over eight hundred miles long, called the Sand River in ancient times, with no flying birds above and no running beasts below, and no water or grass.
At that time, looking at the shadow, there was only one, just thinking of AvalokitÃªÅ›vara Bodhisattva and the Heart Sutra of the Perfection of Wisdom.
At first, when the Dharma Master was in Shu, he saw a sick person, with foul-smelling body sores, and tattered clothes, feeling pity, he took him to the temple and gave him clothes and food expenses.
The sick person, feeling ashamed, then gave this sÅ«tra to the Dharma master, who always recited and practiced it.

When he reached the Sha River area, he encountered evil ghosts of strange appearances surrounding him, even though he was reciting the Guanyin mantra, they would not leave. When he recited this sÅ«tra, they all scattered. He was saved from danger, truly relying on it.
At that time, he traveled over a hundred li, lost his way, and could not find Wild Horse Spring.
He wanted to drink water, but the bag was heavy, and he overturned it by mistake. The provisions for a thousand-li journey were exhausted in a single day.
Again, he lost his way, wandering around without knowing where to go, and wanted to return to the fourth beacon tower in the east.
After traveling for more than ten li, he thought to himself:
I made a vow before that if I did not reach India, I would not return east even one step. Why am I coming now?
It would be better to die going west, how could I return east and live?
Thereupon, he turned his horse's head, focused his thoughts on Guanyin, and proceeded northwest.
At that time, looking around in all directions, it was vast and empty, with no people or birds.
At night, strange creatures raised fires, blazing like many stars, and during the day, violent winds carried sand, scattering like timely rain.
Although encountering such things, my mind was fearless, but suffering from the exhaustion of water, I was thirsty and could not move forward.

At that time, for four nights and five days, not a single drop touched my throat. My mouth and stomach were dry and parched, and I was on the verge of death, unable to move forward. I then lay down in the sand and silently contemplated Guanyin. Although exhausted, I did not give up.
I addressed the Bodhisattva, saying:
This journey of mine is not for the sake of wealth or fame, but solely for the supreme true Dharma.
I respectfully consider the Bodhisattva's compassionate care for all beings, taking the relief of suffering as one's duty.
This is suffering indeed, how could you not know?
In this way, I spoke with each thought, without ceasing.
In the middle of the fifth night, a cool breeze suddenly touched my body, refreshing me as if I had bathed in cold water.
His eyes became clear, and the horse was able to get up.
When his body had recovered and he had slept a little,
he dreamed of a huge deity several tens of feet tall, holding a halberd and saying:
Why don't you walk on? Why are you sleeping again?
The Dharma Master was startled awake and continued on his way. After walking about ten li, the horse suddenly took a different path and could not be turned back.
After several li, he suddenly saw several mu of green grass, so he dismounted and let it eat.

Ten steps away from the grass, he wanted to turn around, but he came to a pool. The water was sweet and clear like a mirror. He went to drink from it, and his life was saved. Both the man and the horse were able to recover.
This must not be ordinary water and grass. It is certainly the compassionate and sympathetic manifestation of the Bodhisattva. His sincerity communicates with the spirits, all of this kind.
He stayed at the grass and pool for one day to rest. The next day, he filled his water container, took some grass, and set off. After two more days, he finally left the desert and arrived at Yiwu.
Such dangers and difficulties, hundreds and thousands, cannot be fully described.
When they arrived in Yiwu, they stayed in a temple.

In the temple there were three Chinese monks, among whom there was an elder who, with his clothes not even enough to cover his waist, came out barefoot to greet them. He embraced the Dharma Master and wept, sobbing and choking, unable to stop. He said:
How could I have expected to see a fellow countryman again today!
The Dharma Master also wept in response.
The non-Chinese monks and the Hu king all came to pay their respects. The king invited them to his residence and made extensive offerings.
At that time, Gaochang King Qu Wentai had people staying in Yiwu beforehand. On that day, they were about to return and happened to meet the Dharma Master. They reported back to their king.

When the king heard this, he immediately sent a messenger to order the king of Yiwu to send the Dharma Master. He also selected dozens of fine horses and sent a noble minister to drive camels and set up a reception to welcome him.
After staying for more than ten days, the king's messenger arrived and presented the king's intention, inviting him with sincere respect.

The master intended to go to the Khan's Buddha statue, but since he was invited by Gaochang, he could not decline and thus proceeded. He crossed the southern desert for six days and arrived at Bailishi City in the territory of Gaochang.
At that time, it was already evening. The master wanted to stay, but the officials and envoys of the city said:
The king's city is nearby, please proceed.
They changed to good horses several times and went ahead, while the master's previous red horse was left for the envoys to follow later.
At the time of the cock's crowing that night, they reached the king's city.
The gatekeeper informed the king, and the king ordered the gate to be opened.

The master entered the city. The king, with attendants lined up with candles in front and back, came out of the palace himself to welcome the master into the rear courtyard, where he sat in a jeweled tent on a multi-storied pavilion.
He paid homage and asked about the master's well-being in a very sincere manner.
He said:
Since I heard the master's name, I have been so happy that I forgot to sleep and eat.
Judging from the road you traveled, I knew you would definitely arrive tonight. I and my wife and children have all been awake, reading sutras and respectfully waiting for you.
Soon, the queen also came with several dozen maids to pay homage.
By then, it was getting close to dawn. After a long time, they became tired and wanted to sleep. The king only returned to the palace, leaving several eunuchs to stay overnight.
In the morning, before the Dharma master had gotten up, the king had already arrived at the door, leading the queen and others to come and pay respects.
The king said:
I thought the desert road would be difficult to travel, and that the master would be able to come alone, which is very amazing.
He shed tears of praise, unable to stop.

He then prepared food to break the fast. After finishing, by the side of the palace there was a separate practice hall where the king personally led the Dharma master to stay, sending eunuchs to guard him.

There was a Dharma master named Tuan who had studied in Chang'an and was well-versed in the characteristics of dharmas. The king treasured him and ordered him to come and meet the Dharma master, leaving after a short while.
He also ordered the national preceptor Dharma master, who was over eighty years old, to stay with the Dharma master, and sent him to encourage him to stay and not go to the West.
The Dharma master did not agree.
After staying for more than ten days, he wanted to take his leave. The king said:
I have already ordered the commander to consult with you. What do you think, Master?
The Dharma Master replied:
Staying here is truly the king's kindness, but my heart cannot be changed. The king said:
I have traveled to the great countries with the previous king.
I have seen many famous monks in the Eastern and Western capitals, Yan, Dai, Fen, and Jin, but my heart has not been moved.

Since hearing the Dharma Master's name, my body and mind have been filled with joy, dancing with delight. I look forward to the Dharma Master's arrival, to receive my offerings and serve him for the rest of my life.

I order the people of the entire country to become the Dharma Master's disciples. I hope the Dharma Master will lecture and teach. Although the number of monks is small, there are still several thousand. I will have them hold scriptures and fill the audience of the Dharma Master.
I humbly hope that you will consider my sincere heart and not think of traveling to the west. The Dharma Master thanked him, saying:
How can a poor monk with few virtues deserve the king's deep kindness?

But this journey is not for the sake of offerings. What I pity is that the Dharma in my homeland is not yet complete, and the scriptures are lacking. I have doubts and confusions, but there is no one to ask for guidance.

For this reason, I will go to the West to the end of my life to request the teachings I have not heard, wishing to make sure that the sweet dew of the Vaipulya scriptures is not only sprinkled in Kapilavastu, and that the subtle words can be fully enjoyed in the Eastern Land. The determination of Paramartha to inquire about the Way, and the heart of Sudhana to seek friends, can only be strengthened day by day. How can I stop halfway?
I wish the King would change his mind and not harbor the idea of keeping me.
The King said:
I admire and enjoy the Dharma Master, and I will definitely keep him for offerings. Even if the Onion Mountains can be moved, this intention will not change.
Please believe in my sincerity and do not doubt that it is not true.
The Dharma Master replied:
How could the King's deep heart be known only after repeated words?
But Xuanzang came to the West for the Dharma. Since the Dharma has not yet been obtained, I cannot stop halfway.
With this respectful message, I wish the king would understand.

Moreover, Your Majesty has cultivated superior karma in the past, and now holds the position of ruler. Not only do the people rely on you, but the Buddhist teachings also depend on you. It is appropriate to assist and promote them, how could it be right to create obstacles?
The king said:
I also dare not create obstacles. It's just that the country lacks a guiding teacher, so I humbly retain the Dharma Master to lead the ignorant and deluded.
The Dharma Master declined all invitations.
The king then changed his expression, rolled up his sleeves, and said loudly:
I have other methods to keep the teacher here. How can you leave by yourself?
Either I will definitely keep you here, or I will send you back to your country. Please think it over yourself.
It would still be better to comply.
The Dharma Master replied:
Xuanzang came here for the great Dharma. Now encountering obstacles, my bones may be left behind by the king, but my consciousness may not be detained.
He then wept uncontrollably.
The king did not accept this either and ordered them to increase their offerings.
Every day when the food was served, the king himself would hold the tray.
Since the Dharma master was detained and prevented from fulfilling his original intention, he vowed not to eat in order to move their hearts.
Thus, he sat upright and did not take even water or juice for three days.
On the fourth day, the king noticed that the Dharma master's breath was gradually weakening, and he deeply felt ashamed and afraid. He then bowed his head in apology and said:
Allow the master to go west. Please eat early.
Fearing it was not true, the Dharma master insisted that the king set a date.
The king said:
If that is necessary, then let us go before the Buddha together and make a cause and condition.
They then entered the temple together to pay homage to the Buddha. Facing Mother Zhang Taifei, they made an agreement with the Dharma master to be brothers, allowing the master to seek the Dharma.
When returning, they requested the master to stay in the country for three years to accept the offerings of the younger brother.
If you will attain Buddhahood in the future, I wish to be your disciple like King Prasenajit and BimbisÄra, and be your lay supporter and protector.
Please stay for one month to lecture on the Benevolent Kings SÅ«tra, and in the meantime I will prepare robes for you.
The Dharma Master agreed to all.
The Empress Dowager was very happy and wished to be the Dharma Master's relative for generations to come, to be reborn together and liberate each other, and then they ate together.
Her determination and integrity were like this.

Later, the king set up a large tent to hold lectures, which could accommodate more than three hundred people. The Empress Dowager and others, the king, the Dharma Master, and the ministers, each listened separately.
Every time there was a lecture, the king personally held an incense burner and came to welcome him.
When about to ascend the Dharma seat, the king also knelt down to provide a step for the Dharma Master to step on. This was done every day.
After the lectures, four novice monks were ordained for the Dharma Master to serve him.
Thirty sets of Dharma robes were made.
Since the Western Regions are mostly cold, he also made face covers, hand covers, boots, and felt boots, each in several pieces.
One hundred taels of gold, thirty thousand silver coins, and five hundred bolts of silk and satin were given to the Dharma Master for his twenty-year journey.
Thirty horses and twenty-five servants were provided.
The Palace Attendant and Imperial Inspector Huan Xin was sent to escort him to the camp of the Yeghe Qaghan.
Twenty-four sealed letters were also written to the twenty-four countries including Kucha.
One bolt of large silk was attached to each letter as a token of faith.
Five hundred bolts of silk and satin and two carts of fruit were offered to the Yeghe Qaghan, with a letter stating:

The Dharma Master is the younger brother of the slave. He wishes to seek the Dharma in the Brahmanic countries. I pray that the Qaghan will have pity on the teacher as he has on the slave. I also request an edict to provide Uighur horses for the twenty-four countries to the west to escort him out of the border.
When the Dharma Master saw the king sending the novice monk and the country's letter and silk to him, he was ashamed of the generosity of the gifts and wrote a letter of thanks, saying:
I have heard that the rivers and seas are vast and deep, and those who cross them must rely on boats and rafts;
Sentient beings are mired in delusion, and those who guide them must truly rely on the holy teachings.
Therefore, the TathÄgata, with the great compassion of a single child, was born in this defiled world;
Reflecting the wisdom sun of the three illuminations, he illuminates this dark and dim place.

The cloud of compassion covers the heavens above the peak of existence, and the Dharma rain moistens the three thousand worlds. Having already benefited and comforted, he abandons his response and returns to truth.

The bequeathed teachings flowed eastward for more than six hundred years. An Shigao and Zhi Qian shone brightly in Wu and Luoyang, while Kang Senghui and KumÄrajÄ«va were renowned in Qin and Liang. They did not let the profound teachings decline, all supporting the excellent practices.

However, distant people came to translate, and the pronunciation and interpretation were different. As time passed after the Sage's passing, the meanings and categories became divergent, causing the TathÄgata's teachings of a single flavor at the twin Å›Äla trees to be divided into the two eternal truths of the present and the future;
The great non-dualistic teaching of the Mahayana was divided into the Northern and Southern schools.
There were disputes and arguments for several hundred years.
The entire country was filled with doubts, and no one could resolve them.
Xuanzang, due to his past causes and conditions, entered the monastic order early and carried his books to follow his teachers for nearly twenty years.

He consulted with famous and virtuous friends, and briefly obtained to read the teachings of the Mahayana and Hinayana, and he often hesitated when holding the scriptures and felt uneasy when holding the sutras. He looked up to Jetavana with longing and thought of Vulture Peak with a heavy heart, wishing to pay homage and ask to resolve his long-standing doubts.

However, he knew that a short tube could not see the sky, and a small flute was difficult to measure the ocean. He could not abandon this sincere wish, so he packed his belongings and took the road. He traveled through various places and finally arrived in Yiwu.

I humbly think that the great king inherits the pure harmony of Heaven and Earth, and is endowed with the virtuous qi of the two polarities. He rules the land, nurturing the people. In the east, he follows the ways of the great states; in the west, he governs the customs of the hundred tribes. The lands of Loulan and Yuezhi, and the regions of Weishi and Langwang, are all embraced by his deep benevolence and share in his abundant virtue.

Moreover, he respects the worthy and loves the scholars, delights in goodness and extends his compassion. He worries about and takes pity on those who come from afar, bending his rules to welcome and guide them.
After arriving, the kindness he bestows is even deeper. He gives them talks and elucidates the meaning of the Dharma.

He also establishes the bond of brotherhood with them, encouraging the thought of friendship. He sends letters to more than twenty western regions, with warm and sincere expressions, ordering them to escort them along the way.

Moreover, he pitied me for traveling alone to the west, on a snowy road in freezing cold, and issued a clear edict to ordain four novice monks to be my companions, providing more than fifty items such as Dharma robes, cotton hats, fur blankets, and boots, as well as silk, gold, and silver coins, enough for twenty years of travel back and forth.

I was shocked and ashamed, not knowing what to do. The water of the Jiaohe River is not considered a great favor when compared to the grace. Lifting the mountains of the Pamirs, how could the favor be heavy?
Crossing the dangerous Lingshui River, I will no longer worry;
In the village of Tianti Dao Tree, I will not look up to the sky in despair.
If I am allowed to do so, whose power is this?
It is the king's grace.

Then I will visit the various masters, receive the true Dharma, return and translate, widely spreading what has not been heard, cutting through the dense forest of various views, ending the digging of heterodox teachings, supplementing the remaining gaps in the Dharma of images, and determining the guide to the profound gate. I hope that this slight merit will repay the extraordinary grace.
Moreover, since the previous journey was far, I was unable to stay long. Tomorrow, I will take leave and depart, and the sadness will increase even more.
I am unable to bear the gratitude. I respectfully write this letter to express my thanks.
The king replied:
Since the Dharma Master has agreed to be brothers, then what the state possesses is shared with the master. Why express gratitude?
On the day of departure, the king, together with the monks, ministers, and common people, left the capital and saw him out of the western gate.
The king embraced the Dharma Master and wept bitterly. The monks and laypeople all grieved, and the sound of parting sorrow shook the suburbs and villages.
The king ordered the queen and the common people to return, and he himself, together with the great virtuous ones and below, rode on horses to see him off for dozens of miles before returning.

The kings and nobles of the countries he passed through all treated him with such respect.ğŸ”½From here, going west, he passed through the cities of Wuban and Dujin, and then entered the country of Agni (formerly mistakenly called Wuji).
